description: Separate workorder-mcp from docs-mcp. Currently workorder-related tools (gather-context, create-plan, execute-plan, update-task-status, archive-feature, etc.) are embedded within docs-mcp alongside pure documentation tools. This refactoring extracts workflow tools into a separate MCP server while maintaining backward compatibility and zero disruption to existing workflows.
goal: Achieve clean separation of concerns: docs-mcp becomes pure documentation (generate docs, audit, standards), workorder-mcp becomes pure workflow (context, plan, execute). Both MCPs access shared filesystem and git infrastructure. Enables independent evolution and testing of each system.
requirements: Phase 1: Build workorder-mcp alongside docs-mcp (no breaking changes)
Phase 2: Dual-run testing with both MCPs active (verify no conflicts)
Phase 3: Gradual migration of slash commands to workorder-mcp (test individually)
Phase 4: Keep docs-mcp as backup until confident workorder-mcp is stable
Phase 5: Clean removal of workflow tools from docs-mcp (once stable)
Maintain backward compatibility during entire refactor
Enable single source of truth via symlinks/shared folders
Automate testing to catch integration issues early
Minimize risk with incremental migration approach
out_of_scope: Redesigning the workflow architecture (only extracting existing tools)
Building new features during refactoring (focus on separation)
Changing tool APIs or behavior (tools work identically)
Removing docs-mcp tools prematurely (keep as fallback)
Rushing to single-MCP deployment before Phase 4
constraints: Existing slash commands must continue working
Must maintain shared coderef/workflow folder (single source of truth)
Performance: No slowdown from additional MCP registration
Safety: Always have fallback to docs-mcp tools if workorder-mcp fails
Testing: Each phase must pass validation before proceeding to next
